data.title: Setting ctrl+f<num> on Mac as a Keyboard shortcut does not work
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.1
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.3
- Locales: cs_CZ

Steps to Reproduce:

1. set some grunt task to be runnable by keybinding "ctrl+f6" in keybindings.json
2. press "ctrl+f6"
3. nothing happens...it does not work
4. try to set it to e.g. "cmd+f6"
5. press "cmd+f6"
6. it works!

Thanks a lot!

data.body:

- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.5.0
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|empty-indent|DmitryDorofeev|0.2.0|
|beautify|HookyQR|0.8.8|
|minify|HookyQR|0.3.0|
|vscode-paste-and-indent|Rubymaniac|0.0.8|
|html-snippets|abusaidm|0.1.0|
|vscode-theme-onedark|akamud|1.3.1|
|project-manager|alefragnani|0.13.2|
|path-intellisense|christian-kohler|1.2.0|
|githistory|donjayamanne|0.1.5|
|phpunit|emallin|1.0.0|
|php-debug|felixfbecker|1.10.0|
|php-intellisense|felixfbecker|1.1.3|
|auto-close-tag|formulahendry|0.3.9|
|code-runner|formulahendry|0.6.13|
|vs-code-phpunit-snippets|jameshrisho|0.0.2|
|theme-onedark-sublime|joshpeng|0.3.6|
|indent-rainbow|oderwat|0.4.1|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a php file
2. Call a method from a class outside of the class file
3. Find all references for that method while inside that class file.
4. It hangs, doesn't find the call you created in 2.

data.title: Exclude commonly generated files from search
Revert git change by clicking on a git change gutter indication

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.1
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.3

This is a feature request.

It would be really helpful if the gutter indication of a git change could be revertable by clicking on that indication. NetBeans has it and it's unbelievably addictive. Especially during prototyping.

And how it could work? If there is a "git change gutter indication", then after the click on such indication, the context menu (maybe just a small graphics with a "back" icon) could appear with an option to "Revert" that chunk.

Just try it, you will definitely love it!

Thanks a lot.

data.title: Can't spawn long-running process from debug adapter
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.1
- OS Version: Windows 7

In [my debug adapter](https://github.com/hbenl/vscode-firefox-debug) I want to be able to spawn Firefox as a long-running process so that future debugging sessions can re-attach to it:
```
let childProc = spawn(firefoxPath, args, { detached: true, stdio: 'ignore' });
childProc.unref();
```
However, on Windows the Firefox process is still terminated at the end of the debugging session.

I am now using a workaround: I use `fork` to create another node process and spawn Firefox from there - now Firefox keeps running at the end of the debugging session.

data.title: Add ability to open untitled document with initial content
data.body:
Addresses #21413 by passing file contents down to the `UntitledEditorModel`.

I checked that it worked locally and I added a test case, but I've had issues getting tests to run as reported in #22019.

data.title: Cannot find module 'original-fs' when running vs code test task on windows
data.body:
OS: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Clone, install, and open vscode
```
git clone https://github.com/microsoft/vscode
cd vscode
scripts\npm install
code .
```
2. Use `ctrl+b` to run the build task. After it completes, terminate the task
3. Open the command palette and "Run test task"

**Expected:** test task runs
**Actual:** Error

> [18:07:19] Using gulpfile c:\PATH\vscode\gulpfile.js
> [18:07:19] Starting 'test'...
> { errorCode: 'load',

>        at Function.Module._resolveFilename (module.js:440:15)
>        at Function.Module._load (module.js:388:25)

>        at C:\PATH\vscode\out\vs\loader.js:519:156
>        at ReadFileContext.callback (C:\PATH\vscode\out\vs\loader.js:622:25)

data.title: [decorators] After decoration on a line with just whitespace incorrectly places the cursor
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.11.0-insider (84e56fc527047223a6ad22c31a906d4a579680d0, 2017-03-03T07:04:55.533Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.4.0

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Add an after decoration to a line that nothing but whitespace (space/tab) -- must also have visible whitespace off (note that the underline shown below, doesn't have any effect on this behavior -- it happens with or without any other decorations)

![decoration](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/641685/23589279/04914ef8-0198-11e7-8e4d-889cd68f6d6b.gif)

2. See that the cursor is positioned incorrectly at the end of the after decorator, rather than at the end of the content (like it does for non-whitespace only lines)

data.title: [decorators] After decoration can extend the length of other decorations
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.11.0-insider (84e56fc527047223a6ad22c31a906d4a579680d0, 2017-03-03T07:04:55.533Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.4.0

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Add an after decoration to a line that has another decoration that spans the whole line, see below

![decoration](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/641685/23589312/8be0ae62-0198-11e7-87e0-f5bae7569697.gif)

2. See that the line decoration expands into the after decoration

data.title: Cannot debug Electron sample using "Node.js: Electron Main" launch.json template
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

### Description

I am unable to debug the [Electron Quick Start sample](https://github.com/electron/electron-quick-start) in VS Code using the "Node.js: Electron Main" _launch.json_ configuration template.

Although the code appears to stop at placed breakpoints, there is no call stack displayed. Instead the following error is displayed:

> "No call stack available (vscode_backtrace: Internal error: TypeError: undefined is not a function)"

**Note:** about once in every blue moon of starting debug, it actually works(!) This issue is temperamental, but definitely on the side of 'not working' much much more than it does work. I did not notice anything different during the times it does work.

### Version info

- VSCode Version: 1.10.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro (x64) 1607 (Build 14393.693)
- Node.js version: v6.9.2
- `electron/electron-quick-start` repository: current head of master as of 2017-03-05 ([`f8ae670c`](https://github.com/electron/electron-quick-start/tree/f8ae670ce85ce7329580b1085e37abb62ea3566b))

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Clone `electron/electron-quick-start` repository
2. `npm install`
3. Open repository folder in VSCode
4. Debug tab > Configuration drop-down > Add configuration
5. In _launch.json_ editor click Add Configuration... button > Node.js: Electron Main
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5658207/23588454/a3a4fffe-01b5-11e7-908a-df9c2c5331df.png)

6. Add a breakpoint anywhere in _main.js_ (e.g., line 16: `mainWindow = new BrowserWindow(...)`)
7. Start debugging using the "Electron Main" configuration

#### Expected

- Stop at breakpoint placed in _main.js_ and line is highlighted
- Debug tab shows the call stack

#### Actual

- Stop at breakpoint placed in _main.js_ but line is **not** highlighted
- Debug tab shows **an error: "No call stack available (vscode_backtrace: Internal error: TypeError: undefined is not a function)"**

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5658207/23588359/777e4256-01b4-11e7-97f3-f82647100ea3.png)


### _launch.json_

```json
{
    "version": "0.2.0",
    "configurations": [
        {
            "type": "node",
            "request": "launch",
            "name": "Electron Main",
            "runtimeExecutable": "${workspaceRoot}/node_modules/.bin/electron",
            "windows": {
                "runtimeExecutable": "${workspaceRoot}/node_modules/.bin/electron.cmd"
            },
            "program": "${workspaceRoot}/main.js",
            "protocol": "legacy"
        }
    ]
}
```

data.title: support cloning git repos or switching branches via URLs

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I [noticed](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-docs/issues/791) that we can open files via URLs nicely in VS Code (docs: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-docs/blob/master/docs/editor/codebasics.md#opening-vs-code-with-urls).

I spotted this [Chrome plugin today for IDEA](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/jetbrains-toolbox-extensi/offnedcbhjldheanlbojaefbfbllddna?hl=en) which adds an `Open in IDEA` button to Chrome when looking at github. It'd be cool to have something like this for VS Code when viewing github projects, branches or PRs so folks can click from the github site in Chrome and it'd prompt the user to clone the git repo with 1 click. 

We'd just need to add some UI support to let the user pick where to clone the git repo or to switch branches etc.

data.title: Starting code from Total Commander opens and keeps cmd open
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro version 1607 - build 14393.693

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Start Total Commander
2. In the command prompt textbox on the bottom type ```code```
3. Visual Studio Code starts, but also with cmd window, which doesn't close by itself. I can close that cmd and the Code instance still lives.

I just don't get why the cmd window won't close itself, if it isn't required to be opened for code to run.

Starting code from Total Commander:
![](http://i.imgur.com/Qiy1Me6.png)

Started code, which also started cmd window:
![](http://i.imgur.com/z4gZaXE.png)

Closed cmd window, but code is still running fine:
![](http://i.imgur.com/lahG7nU.png)

data.title: Wrong information about references
data.body:
- VS Code version: 1.10.1
- OS version: Linux Ubuntu 16.04
- Settings: `"typescript.referencesCodeLens.enabled": true`
- **Problem**: Class `App` is used in 4 places, shows `0 references`
- _Fix_: Open files where class `App` is used and when go check class `App` again, it will shows `4 references`
- **How it should be**: You don't need to open files where class `App` is used to see all references

data.title: Add Command for navigating around visible editors/viewlets/repl
Cached text remains even after deleting.
data.body:
Hello,

- VSCode Version: 1.10.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open up `script.js`, already contains `id` (some js variable)
2. Select all content & press Del (_I mean I deleted all `script.js`'s content_)
3. if I start typing `i`, VSCode show me `id` as suggestion. it got happens after about 30 minutes later too, so seems like the cached items remains until re-open VSCode.

p.s: `id` here is just an example. also I'm not sure it happens in other editors (css, html, ...) too.

Thanks!

data.title: Quick copy lines in diff view
data.body:
When I'm comparing files before I commit them to Git, it would often be useful to quickly revert a hunk by clicking some small arrow like this (I'm not a designer):

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/101152/23585829/56d5e3c8-0188-11e7-85db-23b696ae088a.png)

I use a similar feature in Beyond Compare (note that in this example, both sides are editable hence the arrows work in both directions):

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/101152/23585835/86824684-0188-11e7-9f73-135b51a3baf7.png)

data.title: Windows Download is unavailable
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version:
- OS Version:

data.title: Suggestion: Offer a secondary slower release cycle?
data.body:
The amount of work done in this project is amazing and highly commendable. Thank you!

However if Visual Studio Code wants to become more popular I feel like a slower release cycle would be welcomed as professionals can avoid issues that happen after speedy releases. Things / bugs / issues slip through too easily on the monthly release cycle and sometimes new functionality is not wanted or needed, at least not for a while.

Therefor I would like to offer this suggestion: 

Can we create two release paths for Visual Studio Code: a fast-lane (current monthly releases) and a slower lane of quarterly releases?

Of course, bug fixes and patches could be released still on a monthly basis.

People can then pick if they would prefer updates faster or like to stick with an existing release longer.
Thanks for reading and your consideration.

data.title: Adjust function focusLast, "end key" now goes to last result(resolves #21096).
data.body:
Goodmorning,

To resolve #21096 , I adjusted the function `focusLast` in `src\vs\base\parts\tree\browser\treeImpl.ts`.
The problem was that only the last element was retrieved, but never checked if that element has any children, so in case the last element is a folder it would focus the folder instead of the files it contains.
Note that I created a while loop to check for children, since multiple folders could be nested.

Since I'm not familiar with the `treeImpl.ts`, please let me know if anything needs to be adjusted.
